title.narrative: CHAI: Strengthening Accountability for the PeaCe Health programme
CHAI: Strengthening Accountability for the PeaCe Health programme

description.narrative: Stöd till den internationella organisationen Clinton Health Access Initiative, CHAI, som ger tekniskt stöd till hälsoministeriet i samordning, översyn och rapportering av hälsoprogrammet PeaCe Health under åren februari 2021 till december 2024, liksom stöd till särskilda åtgärder som rör socialt och finansiellt ansvarsutkrävande under programperioden.

Support to the international NGO Clinton Health Access Initiative, CHAI, for assisting the Ministry of Health with the coordination, monitoring and management of the PeaCe Health programme during February 2021 to December 2024 with specific measures aimed at strengthening social and financial accountability during the programme duration.

The overall objective of the Project is to strengthening accountability and program coordination in the PeaCe Health program through 5 main pathways; 1. Improved People-Centered RMNCAH/N Programme Management and Coordination. 2. Adoption of Integrated People-Centered Health Care Services approach in the provision of RMNCAH/N services and improved Human Resources. 3. Improved Programme Performance, Monitoring and Resource Allocation. 4. Improved Documentation, Dissemination and Learning. 5. Improved Financial Accountability for the PeaCe Health Programme.

title.narrative: Decision on Contribution CHAI Strengthening Accountability RMNCAH/N Phase II

description.narrative:
The Government of Zambia is implementing the People at the Center of Health (PeaCe Health) program with financial support from the Embassy of Sweden in Zambia. The PeaCe Health program's overall objective is to equip the health systems, including the community health systems in Eastern and Southern provinces, to deliver quality, people-centered, rights-based, and equity-focused Sexual, Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn, Child and, Adolescent & Nutrition (SRMNCAH&N) services. The program will run from 2021 to 2022 with a possibility for an extension. The Clinton Health Access Initiative (CHAI) was engaged to implement a complementary project to address the challenges faced in the RMNCAH&N program as well as strengthen coordination and accountability on the PeaCe Health Program. The complementary project is known as the "Strengthening Accountability and Coordination for PeaCe health Program." The program was able to achieve the expected results for the period as illustrated by some of the results below.
Objective 1: Improve People-Centered SRMNCAH&N Program Management & Coordination
CHAI supported the Ministry of Health to review and finalize the PeaCe Health program document, budget, risk matrix, and draft results framework.
The Program Implementation Committee (PIC) comprising of MoH, CHAI, and Embassy of Sweden was constituted to ensure a coordinated response in delivering quality SRMNCAH&N services on the PeaCe Health program.
CHAI supported MoH in conducting a partner mapping for Eastern and Southern provinces. The exercise mapped out the partners supporting the various SRMNCAH&N thematic areas.
CHAI participated and provided input during consultative meetings for developing the 2022 -2026 National Health Strategic Plan (NHSP) and 2022 -2026 Adolescent Health Strategy.
In order to ensure participatory planning and equity across the SRMNCAH&N program thematic areas for Integrated People-Centered Health Care Services (IPCHCS), CHAI supported MoH in developing need-based work plans for hospitals, districts, and provincial health offices in Southern and Eastern provinces.
To strengthen program resilience to emerging health system disruptions, CHAI supported COVID-19 surveillance meetings in Eastern and Southern provinces.
Objective 2: Adoption of IPCHCS approach in the provision of SRMNCAH&N Services and Improved Human Resources
In collaborated with WHO, CHAI supported MoH to develop the Integrated People-Centered Health Care Services (IPCHCS) guidelines and facilitator's guide.
Recruitment, induction, and deployment of 22 full-time staff. 11 seconded to the MoH at the national and provincial levels and the remaining 11 based at the CHAI office. CHAI and the MoH have finalized the recruitment of the Neonatal and Child Health Officer who will start work on the 1st of July 2022.
Supported the MoH to update its Establishment Register (ER). This register allows the MoH to track healthcare worker distribution within the health system.
Objective 3: Improve Program Performance, Monitoring, and Resource Allocation
To strengthen systems for tracking people centered SRMNCAH&N services, CHAI and MoH conducted a baseline and needs assessments in 687 facilities across the two provinces to assess the availability of the essential commodities, equipment, supplies, infrastructure, and skills of the health care workers.
CHAI developed Activity Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning (AMEL) plan for the Strengthening Accountability and Coordination project and the PeaCe Health program.
CHAI supported the MoH to develop a the Results Based Financing (RBF) model and the selection of incentivized indicators for RBF is ongoing.
Objective 4: Improve Documentation, Dissemination, and Learning
To improve reporting, standardized reporting templates were developed using a consultative process. CHAI, working closely with MoH, identified, and trained 58 focal point persons in report writing, and documenting success stories. The software Navision was agreed upon as the planning tool for the program.
CHAI developed the Documentation and Dissemination (D&D) plan that articulates the various knowledge products to be generated on the program, target audiences, the best medium, and frequency of dissemination. The D&D plan will strengthen communication on the program to inform policy, practice, and future implementation.
Objective 5. Improve Financial Accountability for People Centered RMNCAHN Service Delivery
CHAI supported the standardization of workplan activities in Microsoft Dynamics Navision (NAV) to streamline the planning and reporting process across institutions. The quarter four 2021 work plans were developed in NAV.
Trainings in the use of NAV for users and approvers were done. These trainings were targeted at enhancing programmatic and financial reporting as well as approval processes to strengthen financial accountability in the utilization of financial resources.
Objective 6: Cross-cutting areas
CHAI supported the MoH to conduct a gender analysis to support strengthening the gender perspective in health service delivery with data collection taking place. A draft report is expected in 2022.
CHAI supported the MoH to develop a PeaCe Health program risk register and risk response plan that documents program vulnerability and prescribes response strategies to reduce overall program vulnerability.
Together with technical teams drawn from the MoH headquarters and provincial health offices, CHAI conducted engineering surveys at 81 sites across all 27 PeaCe Health supported districts. The engineering survey results have been used to inform the final selection of sites for targeted infrastructure investments. Draft construction drawings, bills of quantities, and cost estimates have been completed pending MoH reviews and approvals.
Some of the lessons learned during the period are.
• That Government processes have tended to be slower than expected owing to the impact of external shocks brought about by COVID-19, national elections, and procedural impediments around the use of donor funds in the context of the Governments financial management systems.
• Active involvement of the national and sub-national levels at every stage of the planning and implementation process of the project activities will help improve supervision.
• Disbursement of funds for the PeaCe Health program through the Ministry of Finance and Bank of Zambia should take about 12 days or even less for the funds to the Ministry of Health PeaCe health program commercial bank account as long all the necessary documentation is available.
• The requirement to have a USAID technical assistance partner onboard created a delay in operationalizing the Program Implementation Committee for the PeaCe Health program.
• For purposes of supporting the budget planning and expenditure control modules, CHAI established that there were substantial challenges around back-end support for NAV due to ambiguities around who was responsible for the payment of user license fees. A key takeaway from the planning process was that the payment of user fees needed to have been addressed as part of the strengthening accountability program.
• For procurement, it was established that staging levels for programmatic procurements (funding districts versus provinces and national levels) through the government system would prove a decisive factor in implementation success.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
